text: What we’re going to study is geometric shapes.  And for the next three weeks what we’ll be studying is – we have studied two-dimensional shapes before.  Remember when we did rectangles and we did squares – rectangles, squares, and triangles? Well, today we’re going to do three- dimensional shapes.  We studied some of these in third grade, correct?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay, so this is what we’re about for the next three weeks.  By the end of the three weeks we’ll be able to find volume of these -- how much they’ll hold in terms of volume.  In two- dimensional shapes we found area, remember that?
speaker: teacher

text: So in the three-dimensional shapes we’re going to find volume. So you have several objects on your table.  So this lesson we’re really going to try to find out how we can identify the various three-dimensional shapes.  So I’m going to use steps to accomplish that. What is this?
speaker: teacher

text: It’s called a cone.  How many faces?  When we talk about three- dimensional shapes, we talk about faces, which is the correct vocabulary.  So how many faces do you see on a cone? One.  What about, what is this?
speaker: teacher

text: One, two.  How about what is this? What is it called?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay, that’s one name.  It’s a prism.  How many faces does it have?
speaker: teacher

text: All right.  So, if you have a square, how many faces do you have on a square?
speaker: teacher

text: Six.  And all the sides are the same?
speaker: teacher

text: Each and every one.  What is this?
speaker: teacher

text: Are all the sides the same?
speaker: teacher

text: And why is it not the same? What do you notice about the sides? What would you call this?
speaker: teacher

text: An edge, very good.  What would you call here, where two edges meet? You’d call it a what?
speaker: teacher

text: A right angle.  You’d call it a right angle somebody just said. What else would you call it? We learned another name? A vertex.  The mathematical name is a vertex.  Right? And we call these what?  What do we call these?
speaker: teacher

text: A sphere.  Now, how many sides or faces does it have?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  What would you call this?
speaker: teacher

text: It has one rectangular face but all the faces are [inaudible]. It’s a triangular prism.  All right? So we’re going to look at prisms.  This is a revision from third grade, right?
speaker: teacher

text: We’re going to look at cylinders.  And we’re going to describe them.  So if you would take out your math workbook, we’re going to work in pairs.  You two are a pair.  If you have someone beside you, work in a pair.  If you don’t, then work by yourself.  You’re going to need your math book. You’re going to go to Unit 7.  And on this page you’re going to guess the solids.  You want to go to page 1. Please take out page 1.  Page 1 should be a page with lots of … everybody needs to do this. So this is a square prism, right? Sorry, a square pyramid rather. What is half of a sphere called?
speaker: teacher

text: Hemisphere, very good.  Good job of remembering third grade. What I would like you to do is take a look at page 1, and with your partner you want to describe each shape.  So here you are with a cube.  How would you describe that if you had to describe it to somebody who had never seen a cube before? How would you describe it? What are the characteristics? What are the components? You want to write it with your partner, so I’ll come around and visit with you.  So you’re describing them. All three-dimensional figures are solids.  Solid meaning they’re not hollow in any way.  Yes?
speaker: teacher

text: You write it beside the figure.  You and your partner decide how would you describe it.  For example, I am going to describe it, I’m going to use these vocabulary words to describe it, because these are the mathematical terms you use when you’re describing any geometric shape, is that clear? So here is your [chance].  What’s a vertex?
speaker: teacher

text: A corner.  What’s a face? What’s a face? Everybody stop working for a minute.
speaker: teacher

text: A flat side.  Okay, what’s a prism?
speaker: teacher

text: All our shapes are 3D.  What’s a prism?
speaker: teacher

text: They don’t have the same faces.
speaker: student

text: These are all the same faces kind of.  So you have to think about it.  How would you describe a prism?
speaker: teacher

text: There’s sides on this.  This is a prism? This is not a prism.
speaker: teacher

text: It’s like a pyramid, very good.  Very good.  So let’s see. Work with your partner.  How would you describe your [inaudible].  Please put your name and today’s date on it. And then we can share our findings.  What’s today’s date, boys and girls?
speaker: teacher

text: 20th.  So what you want to do is identify the characteristics, at least three characteristics of every shape on your paper.  They’re already named, so you know that’s a cube, the first one, but what are the attributes, what are the characteristics of a cube? Anybody know? Let’s do number one together.  What’s one of the characteristics of a cube? Excuse me? Is that kind of like a cube? Is that like a cube?
speaker: teacher

text: So here you are.  This is a cube.  What can you say about a cube?
speaker: teacher

text: A cube has six faces, so that’s one thing I can say about it. Six faces.  What else?  How many corners?  How many corners or vertices?
speaker: teacher

text: Eight.  What else can you say about it? Is there anything special about the faces, the six faces? Are they six equal faces?
speaker: teacher

text: Yes, they’re equal.  All the sides are equal.  Eight vertices. What else can you say about a cube?
speaker: teacher

text: And it has 12 edges.  So edges is another word.  Do you understand what to do?  Is everybody clear on what to do with each of the figures we have?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  So I’ll just come around and look at what you have.  So what about a rectangular prism when you get to that?
speaker: teacher

text: Do you want to work with… I guess you don’t have the space.  Do you want to turn your table around? Is there anybody not comfortable working by themselves right now? You should pick up each as many as you have… And also your faces, right? Faces, edges, is it a prism, is it a cylinder? [Inaudible] the back sides also.  So here is one, two, three, four. These have four sides.  Have you ever put a box together? Yeah.  Once you put it together, then you have a back side, front side, two sides, bottom side, top side. What do you notice about the shape? They’re rectangular.  Are all sides equal?
speaker: teacher

text: [Inaudible]. What kind of angles are they? Can you be more specific? What kind of angles are they? [Inaudible] Remember you’re trying to describe these.  So if you are looking at something with a cylindrical body like this, you want to say two faces…  Hello.  You want to say two faces and cylindrical body.  Cylinder means the roundness, it’s like a cylinder.  Think about trying to describe this for a child who has never seen these shapes before. There we go, very good. This has how many edges? Four edges, right.  [Inaudible] Some shapes we have to share, guys.  You may have to share your … just a second, yes?
speaker: teacher

text: What do you need to know about a cone?  What do you need to know about a cone?
speaker: teacher

text: How many faces do you see?
speaker: teacher

text: How else could you describe it?
speaker: teacher

text: Okay.  Is it right angles we’re calling them or are we calling them what?
speaker: teacher

text: All right, we’re going to come back together as a group and we’re going to have people from each group describe a shape.  Do you understand that? So that all of us can see if we got all the attributes down. All right, have we completed these six so far?
speaker: teacher

text: Have we completed six of them so far?
speaker: teacher

text: So let’s stop for a minute and I’m just going to go in order of how we’re seated.  The octagonal prism will be you two. The rectangular prism is going to be you two.  And the cylinder is going to be Student F and M.  All right? So let’s start.  Do you have an example of the shape? Very good. We all should be listening.  Pencils down.
speaker: teacher

text: Okay, so can you show us as you talk about these parts? These attributes?
speaker: teacher

text: 8 corners.  All right.  Who is the next group?
speaker: teacher

text: 12 edges.  Okay.  Next group.  So should be taking notes if you missed anything.  Next group please.
speaker: teacher

text: An octagon, they have eight faces.
speaker: student

text: Somebody disagrees with you.  What shape is that?
speaker: teacher

text: How do you know a hexagon?
speaker: teacher

text: One, two, three, four, five, six.  Right?  One side, right? Two, three, four, five, six.  Everybody agrees, there’s six sides?
speaker: teacher

text: You don’t agree? Six faces on the body.  How much is this? One, seven.  How much is this?
speaker: teacher

text: So there are eight faces.  Did you want to finish? You have to show us.  You have to prove it.
speaker: teacher

text: 12 vertices, or 12 edges.   What else? Is it solid? Is it solid? How do you know if something is solid? How do you know if something is solid?
speaker: teacher

text: It’s not hollow.  Is this hollow?
speaker: teacher

text: So it is solid.  If it’s not hollow it’s solid, right? And it’s because it’s a solid, we can find out how much volume it will hold.  Remember when we did area with three- dimensional shapes? We could find out how much it would cover, how much carpet we’d need to do this room.  Well, with a three-dimension shape the measurement that you find is not area but volume, do you understand? Does that make sense?
speaker: teacher

text: So with two-dimensional shapes we find area.  With three- dimensional shapes we find a different measure, which is called volume.  So as long as you don’t get those mixed up, all right? Next group.  Thanks, Student E.  Next group.
speaker: teacher

text: We can’t hear you, Student M.   A cylinder, two faces.  Show us the faces, please.  One, two.  Is it solid? It looks like a?
speaker: teacher

text: Log.  And it looks like a log, she says.  That’s a good description, but is that a mathematical description?
speaker: teacher

text: But it’s helpful for us to describe it.  It’s solid and it’s cylindrical in shape.  Student J, cylindrical in shape, okay? So it’s cylindrical in shape.  All right.  Anybody have any questions about the shapes? You did this in third grade.  Is this a review?
speaker: teacher

text: All the shapes, to be able to identify them.  Did we ever get to the sphere?
speaker: teacher

text: So I want to talk about the sphere.  How would you describe this to someone who has never seen a sphere before?
speaker: teacher

text: No vertices, no faces.  I wouldn’t say no nothing.
speaker: teacher

text: It’s solid.  Could you say it’s round like a ball?
speaker: teacher

text: Is it the same size all around? [Inaudible] This is very interesting.  What about this one, though, what is this?
speaker: teacher

text: It’s half of a sphere.  But the difference is, because it’s half of a sphere, what does it have?
speaker: teacher

text: One face.  So two hemispheres will make up… Two hemispheres make up…
speaker: teacher

text: Mm-hmm.   Student W. says hemi means half and sphere means circle, so really it’s a half circle.  That’s the meaning of the word.  All right. Can we take a look at Unit 7 page 2.  No, page 2 is not going to work for us.  If you look on page 5, what do you notice?
speaker: teacher

text: No, they’re not.  They’re two-dimensional, I agree with you. What else [inaudible].
speaker: teacher

text: If you notice, it is just one face that you’re seeing.  Do you notice that?
speaker: teacher

text: And that is called a silhouette.  What’s a silhouette? Anybody in here ever see their shadow in the dark?
speaker: teacher

text: Or if you are in the sun, or a shadow from a light in a room, and you see a shape of a human being or a body moving, so you can just see the outside.  But these are silhouettes, just an outline of an object.
speaker: teacher

text: It’s similar to a shadow.  So that’s what a silhouette is.  So this is showing you the silhouette of a shape.  If you look at a silhouette of a person, do you know it’s a person?
speaker: teacher

text: So if you’re looking at a silhouette of a three-dimensional shape, could you identify what shape it is?
speaker: teacher

text: How about going on identifying all these shapes with your partner.  Just write the name on them on page 5.  So on page 5, identify by writing the name on the object.  So what is A?
speaker: teacher

text: And geometry what do we call a square?
speaker: teacher

text: So the first one. What do you think B is?
speaker: teacher

text: A rectangular prism. What do you think D is?
speaker: teacher

text: So if that’s a semi-circle, what is G? A semi-circle is a half circle.  So what is G then? If B is a square, what is G, guys?
speaker: teacher

text: A hemisphere, good.  What do you think E is?
speaker: teacher

text: Triangular prism. What do you notice by identifying shapes, boys and girls, the silhouettes.  What do you notice? Anybody notice anything as you identify the names of the silhouettes? Anybody? Student F, do you notice anything? Student A, do you notice anything about the silhouettes?
speaker: teacher

text: Because of the shape, we’re able to identify what they are. [Inaudible] shape that can help us know what they are? So it’s a shape. Some of them could be … All right, guys, before we wrap up.  Just stop for a minute, you can finish these for homework tonight.  Pencils down, please. So what is the most important thing we have done today? Yes, Student A.
speaker: teacher

text: To find the characteristics of our shapes.  What the attributes are, the characteristics of the shapes that we’re working with.  What else are we doing?
speaker: teacher

text: We’re working on describing our shapes, yes.
speaker: teacher

text: Being able to identify a shape by looking at a silhouette of a shape.  Anybody notice that a silhouette could be more than one? For example, B could be this, could it?
speaker: teacher

text: Hemisphere, right? It could also be a…
speaker: teacher

text: Cylinder, okay? So the silhouettes are not always clear, but it’s a start.  Just like you see a shape of a person sometimes through a window with a light on and you’re all in the dark, if the light is on in the house, you may notice it’s the shape of a person.  You may not know if it is a male or a female.  Does that make sense? Because silhouettes are like that…
speaker: teacher

text: You may not be able to sometimes.
speaker: teacher

text: My sister, she was walking before and her hair was in the back and you couldn’t see the roundness and it looked like she was bald.
speaker: student

text: But you understand what I’m trying to say, right?
speaker: teacher
